cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: EGYPTIACA,
div.p: BY JOSEPH OFFORD
In a former portion ot .Egyptiaca mention
was made of an Egyptian ceal in the form of
an Assyrian cylinder bearing the cartooch of
Kameres II, of the 19th dynasty, as being so
Inte in date for that type of signet in Reypt,
that it may have been of Syrian workmanship
Ihe whole subject of the use of this Mesopo
tamiao ‘y.indrical frm of seal by the Ezyptians
bas been somewhat folly treated in Chapter 1
of Mr. Perey E Newberry’s recnt'y pablished
book entitled ‘Scarabs,’ ‘An Introduction to
the Study of Ezyp:ian Seal and Signet Rings.”
Ife therein figures a cylinder of Seti I, pre
jecessor of Rameses Il, with the comment
that it is one of the latest spesimens of a
cylinder known. From tha representation of it
given it appeare to be in perfect preservation
and is interesting for the trellis work ornament
rinning tight round the cylinder ocenpying
half its depth. This relc is in the Petrie
collection at University College, London
There are cylinders bearing the names ot
priva'e personsgaa aslate as the 26th dynasty
but they areextremely rare ‘There is, however,
no great ant arian difficulty in accepting
the Rameses specimen as Egyptian work
Mr. Nowberry gives copies of qiite 109
Egyptian cylinders commencing with that of
Pharaoh Narme, perhaps a pre-Menes mon
arch, and terminating as late as the 26th
dynasty, bat these very late ones are rot
those of royalty
[he reliefs upon the Narmer ard Zer
cylinders (tbe latter successor of Menes) are
far soperior io artistic merit to many archaic
Egyptian specimens, which shorld therefore be
considered to represent products of a mach
earlier period.
It will immediately appear that if this is
ths case, and if this form of seal was intro-
duced into the Nile valley by Babylonian, or
Elamite, invaders, then their incomirg to
Bgypt, from Asia, most bave taken place under
chieftains esrlier than thore whosa names we
have at tha Meves era or of those whom coma
Egyptologista oonsidsr as prejecessors of
Menes. ‘I'he short thick torm of cylinder,
practically identical ia type with the early
Cha'dean and Elamite cylinders, and also, in
many instances, bearing figures closely allied
to those «f Babylonian representations, are
evidently the work of a period far acterior to
thoee we know to date from the first dynasty.
The short, and what may be termed pre
historic, cylinders have been found asac ciated
with larger ones in tombs of tha first dynasty,
bat the first form was appsrently at this early
time a survival, for it vanishes about the
date of King Zer in the first dynasty, whilst
the long onea continued in general use to
the end of the eixth dynasty. A fine member
of one of the last of ita kind, bearing the
title of Merirs, is in the Piers collection in
the United States.
The cylinders of the Shepherd, or Hyksos,
Kings do not show any great difference of
design from Egyptian ones of about the same
era. One of King Kbyan in the Cairo Murenm
is however particoler'y emel! in diameter
whilst beirg rather lorg, viz, sboot 1}
inches, having a resemblance in size to an
ivory needle care.
Scmeof the very archaic cylinders have
for a familiar device the head and fore legs
of ao animal reversed, that i+ to say a fan
tastic animal with beads and fore quarters
looking in opposite directions united together
M. Newberry says this is not an Egyptian
motive, but it cconrs upon the prebistoric
cowba figured by M. Capart. Mr. Newberry
farther suggests it is a design emanating
from the Delta. If so it is extrewely inte
resting that it was a favonrite torm of orna
ment opon some prehistoric antiquities f.om
Sardinia and Sicily
The royal cylinder «f Zr is very simple, bot
significant, in its tablearx. ‘These ara two
totem gnidons with'he jackal nome symbo!
Then the king's Horus name, with the Horus
falcon surmounting it, and then seated fizores
‘ Zer, one bearing the crown of opper and
otber of lower Egypt. So at the time it was
graven the idea of oniting the two in one
symbolic headdre-s, as was usual, later or,
had not been conceived
Cylinde-s have been found of copper and
bronze but the majority are of black steatite
tthe white variety, glazed artificially green
vt blae, Many are of ivory, bwmatite. and
; bat from the many impress ons
preserved it ix
KrLaL Je per
y clay that have been
videot that the commonest material ot'li-ed
was woo}, and a ‘ew wocden ones have been
ond.
Tho use of this furm of seal provides perLaps
the most weighty argument for the connection,
at rome period, in Egypt of African with
Asiatic civilisation, if such a term may be need
speaking of such early races of mankind
l’érbaps on the western littoral of the Red Sea
around Kosseir, or near Suakinr, or at Port
idar, specimens cf cylinders left by voyagers
from Asis to Egypt may be found supplying
connecting link between thore of the
lo'deans and the Egyptians

Bureau for Travellers.

div.head: EGYPTIAN OPTIONS
div.p: The Secretary has sent ont the followin
served at all home naval and military station4 | letter to shareholders _—
on the 29th inst.
Major (local lientenant colonel) E. BE. Bernard
Financial Secretary of the Sodan Administra
tton; and Mejor M. Contte, Assistant Seore
tary, Sudan Administration, have passed tha
tactical test for promotion to the rank of lieu
tenant colonel. Both officers belong to tha
Army Service Corps
Lady Wingate and family are at Stefford
House, Donbar, where Sir Reginald will join
them on arriving home from Egypt.
Colonel G. F. Gorringe, C.M.G, Royal En-
gineers, who bad auch a soccessful career with
the Khedive's troops, has been appointed
Director of Movements and Quarterings at the
Army Headgqnarters.
On retnrning home from Egypt, Captain
B. W. 8. Mahon, Royal Engineers, has been
posted for duty to Longmore Camp, Bast Liss,
in command of No. 8 (Railway) Company.
It is expected that when Colonel (. B. Vy-
vyan vacate: the command of the lst Bat-
talion of the Buffs in Augnat next, he will be
succeeded by Major G. V. Daaglish, second in
command cf the 2nd Battalion, Harrismith.
This ¢ fiver has been connected with the Bofts
for over twenty-six yeare, bas held field rank
for nearly seven years and served in the Chitral
Relief Expedition, 1895 (medal with clasp
and the Sonth African War, including the
operations in the Eastern Transvaal, the action
of Baakenlasgte, &amp ;amp ;c. (twice mentioned in des
patches, Queen's medal with three clasps,
King's medal with two clasps).
It is unders‘ood that Mr. Haldane will make
a formal statement re bis proposed army re-
forms in the House on the 17th prox. Im-
portant economies are to be effected, and
to this end the Army Coanoil is drafting
a scheme. All concerned devoutly wish
that the scheme will not be one of choap
ness at the expense of efficiency. Mr. Haldane
says that be has no intention of destroying 45
batteries cf field artillery.
The exposure of the Chicago borrora has
practically killed the importation of canned
meat into this coontry from the United States,
and pretty near time too. It would be intereat-
ing to know if the tinned dog, cat, and rotten
oxen which were so freely despatched to South
Africa during the war had anything to do
with the fearful diseases which wrought sach
havoc amongst our troops. | beard an : flicer,
presently in Egypt, say, that during the siege
of a certain town, he preferred a slice ct his
dead charger to the canned meat, for he knew
what it was.

div.head: GERMS LIVE TN) MUMMIES
div.p: FAD FOR EGYPTIAN RELICS HAS
SPREAD GREAT WHITE SCOURGE.
Chicago, May 12. — “Egyptology versus
Heslth” was the title of a monograph, received
at the headquarters cf the Tuberculosis Insti-
tate of Chicago yesterdey, in which it was
alleged that the great spread of tubercalcsia
in Europe and Ameiisa inthe last 100 years
found its cause in the di-interment and ship
ment broadcast overthe land of the mommies
which had reposed so long in the tombs of the
Pharaohs. ‘lhe monograph was written by Dr.
Rafaelle Sorynac, one of the lecturers at the
Sorbonne in Paria, who was an interested
visitor at the recent taberculosis exhibition in
this city.
“That the disinterred mammies started the
spread of ‘he t. berculosis germs in Ezypt can-
not ba doub‘ed,” says Dr. Sorgnac in bis
monograph. “There are more tubercolosis
germs in the almost impalpable dust sround a |
mommy cise than in many cuspidors of |
eflavia ‘Ibese germs live fur thousands of |
years, as has easily bean proven, and the,
exhumation of the bodies, evan the wall pre
served ones, caused an epidemic of consump |
ti n among the workmen and scholara who first |
exhomed th cases. It is also well known that
the keepers «f the mammy cases have been |
subject to the disess *
“‘I'be start of tuberculosis in France in a
erious sense may be traced to the great im
portation of mommies and mummy ca‘e3 at the
time of the Napoleonic invation of E:ypt, aud
thie start gave the disease ita first great foot-
hold in Earope, whence it has spread all over
the western world. Dead bodies may not secrete
the germs, but dead dod‘es are andoubtedly a
favourite lodging place tor the tubercular ba-
cilli.
“The bacilli from the mammiesare undoubted
ly of great age, and it bas been ebcwn by
experiment in Paris that these aged bacilli |
are infinitely more deadly than thoee obtained
from the live persons who are infected.”

div.p: Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
